question: Having a driver license is a:
options: "a: Right,b: Privilege,c: Requirement."
note: "The DMV Handbook states that a California driver's license 'allows you to drive on public roads.'"

question: With a Class C driver license, a person may drive:
options: "a: Any three axle vehicle regardless of the weight,b: A vehicle pulling 2 trailers,c: A 3 axle vehicle if the gross vehicle weight is less than 6000 lbs"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'For information on vehicles covered by a Class C, visit dmv.ca.gov/dl.'"

question: You are under 18 years of age and have had your license for eight months. You may drive:
options: "a: At any time.,b: Between 5 a.m. and 11 p.m.,c: Between 7 a.m. and 8 p.m."
note: "According to page 4 of the DMV handbook, 'When you are under 18 years old, your driver's license will have the word provisional. As a provisional driver, you cannot drive:  - Between 11 p.m. and 5 a.m. during the first 12 months you have your license.'"

question: Which of these statements about drugs and traffic is true?
options: "a: Even over-the-counter drugs can impair your driving,b: Any prescription drug is safe to use if you don’t feel drowsy,c: Only illegal drugs can impair your driving"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Prescription and over-the-counter medications can make you an unsafe driver. Some medicines can make you sleepy. It is your responsibility to know the effects of the medications you take.'"

question: Fatigue increases the risk of:
options: "a: Missing an exit.,b: Being late for an appointment.,c: Falling asleep behind the wheel and crashing."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 9 'Fatigue and Drowsiness - Can affect your vision and increase reaction time to hazards.'"

question: What is a potential effect of taking a prescription drug while drinking alcohol?
options: "a: There will likely be no effect.,b: It will make you more alert.,c: It can make you unfit to drive."
note: "The DMV Handbook states, 'Prescription and over-the-counter medications can make you an unsafe driver. Some medicines can make you sleepy.' This implies that taking a prescription drug while drinking alcohol can negatively affect your driving abilities."

question: Which of the following statements is correct?
options: "a: Use your left foot to brake.,b: Use your right foot for both braking and accelerating your vehicle.,c: You should always brake abruptly to ensure stopping."
note: “You should always use your right foot for both braking and accelerating your vehicle. The left foot should not be used.”

question: When parking next to a curb, you should use your turn signals
options: "a: When pulling next to or away from the curb,b: When pulling next to but not away from the curb,c: Only when pulling away from the curb"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'You should signal... Before pulling next to the curb or away from the curb.'"

question: You should signal at least 100 feet before you turn...
options: "a: Before every lane change.,b: At least 5 seconds before you change lanes on a freeway.,c: None of the above.,d: both a and b"
note: "The text states, 'You should signal: At least 100 feet before you turn, Before every lane change., At least five seconds before you change lanes on a freeway.'"

question: You are about to make a left turn. You must signal continuously for how many feet before making the turn?
options: "a: 275 feet,b: 100 feet,c: 50 feet"
note: "According to the California Driver's Handbook, you must signal 'at least 100 feet before you turn.'"

question: You should use your horn when:
options: "a: Another vehicle is in your way.,b: It may help prevent a collision.,c: Another driver makes a mistake."
note: "According to page 10, 'Use your vehicle's horn to let other drivers know you are there or warn others of a hazard. Use your horn to: Avoid collisions.'"

question: When should you signal?
options: "a: Before turning 100 feet before turning.,b: 2100 feet before turning.,c: 3200 feet before turning.,d: none of the above"
note: "The DMV handbook states that drivers should signal 'At least 100 feet before you turn.'"

question: When can you drive using only parking lights?
options: "a: 30 minutes after sunset or 30 minutes before sunrise,b: on foggy days,c: Not under any circumstances"
note: "It is illegal to drive using only parking lights."

question: When should you turn off your turn signal?
options: "a: As soon as you have completed the turn or lane change,b: As soon as you begin the turn or lane change,c: Before you begin the turn or lane change"
note: "You should turn off your signal 'when you no longer need it.'"

question: Dim your high beam headlights to low beams within
options: "a: 200 feet when a vehicle is coming towards you,b: 300 feet when a vehicle is coming towards you,c: 500 feet when a vehicle is coming towards you"
note: "According to The DMV handbook, 'Dim your high-beam headlights to low beams within 500 feet of a vehicle coming toward you or within 300 feet of a vehicle you are following.' This information is found on page 11 of the DMV handbook."

question: When parking next to a curb, you should use your turn signals:
options: "a: Only when pulling away from the curb.,b: When pulling next to but not away from the curb.,c: When pulling next to or away from the curb."
note: "According to the California Driver's Handbook, 'You should signal: ... Before pulling next to the curb or away from the curb.'"

question: Use your headlights on rainy, snowy, or foggy days:
options: "a: To keep your engine warm.,b: So others can see your vehicle.,c: To warn others of bad weather conditions."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Your vehicle's headlights help you see what is in front of you. They also make it easier for other drivers to see your vehicle.'"

question: When both right and left turn signals are flashing at the same time on a moving vehicle, it means
options: "a: It is carrying children to or from school,b: Let the vehicle have the right-of-way,c: There may be a hazard or an accident ahead"
note: "If you can see a collision or hazard ahead, warn drivers behind you using these methods: Turn on your emergency flashers. Lightly tap your brake pedal three or four times. Use a hand signal when slowing and stopping."

question: You should turn on your hazard lights when
options: "a: Driving in heavy rain or fog,b: Your car has broken down on the side of the road,c: You are double parked"
note: "The DMV handbook states 'If you need to stop because of vehicle trouble: - Turn on your emergency flashers. If your vehicle does not have emergency flashers, use your turn signals.'"

question: Flash your brake lights or turn on your emergency flashers if you:
options: "a: Need to warn other drivers of a collision ahead.,b: Are temporarily parked in a traffic lane to make delivery.,c: Are backing out of a parking space."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'If you can see a collision or hazard ahead, warn drivers behind you using these methods: Turn on your emergency flashers, Lightly tap your brake pedal three or four times, Use a hand signal when slowing and stopping.'"

question: If your vehicle has a mechanical problem:
options: "a: Signal and pull into the slow lane.,b: Stop in your lane and put on your hazard lights.,c: Put on your hazard lights and pull off the road."
note: "If you need to stop because of vehicle trouble: Turn on your emergency flashers. If your vehicle does not have emergency flashers, use your turn signals, If possible, pull off the road away from all traffic."

question: You must not cross a solid double line in the center of the roadway to
options: "a: Overtake and pass another vehicle,b: Make a left turn,c: Enter a private driveway"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Do not pass over double solid yellow lines... make a left turn... except at designated openings.'"

question: Treat lines as a barrier. When
options: "a: Two sets of solid double white lines are spaced 2 feet apart,b: Two sets of solid double yellow lines are spaced 2 or more feet apart,c: Two sets of broken yellow lines are spaced 1 foot apart"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Two sets of solid double yellow lines spaced two or more feet apart are considered a barrier. Do not drive on or over this barrier, make a left turn, or make a U-turn across it, except at designated openings.'"

question: A solid yellow line next to a broken yellow line means that vehicles:
options: "a: In both directions may pass.,b: Next to the broken line may pass.,c: Next to the solid line may pass."
note: "A broken yellow line indicates you may pass if the broken line is next to your driving lane. Only pass when it is safe."

question: A broken yellow line beside a solid yellow line indicates that:
options: "a: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the solid yellow line.,b: Passing is not permitted from either direction.,c: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the broken yellow line."
note: "A broken yellow line indicates you may pass if the broken line is next to your driving lane. Only pass when it is safe. "

question: Double solid yellow line markings down the center of a road indicate that passing is:
options: "a: Allowed from both directions.,b: Allowed only from your direction of travel.,c: Not allowed from either direction."
note: "Double solid yellow lines indicate a lane barrier between two-way traffic.  'Do not pass over double solid yellow lines.' "

question: When double solid yellow lines separate lanes of traffic:
options: "a: Passing is permitted from the left.,b: Passing is permitted from the right.,c: Passing is not permitted from either direction."
note: "Double solid yellow lines indicate a lane barrier and passing is not permitted from either direction. 'Do not pass over double solid yellow lines.'"

question: When driving on a multi-lane street with two-way traffic, you should:
options: "a: Drive alongside the other vehicles so the drivers can see you.,b: You should drive ahead of or behind the other vehicles.,c: It is safest to drive in the lane next to the center line."
note: "The DMV handbook states that you should drive ahead or behind the other vehicles to avoid collisions"

question: Changing from one lane to another is best done:
options: "a: Quickly and often.,b: When a car is in your blind spot.,c: Gradually and carefully."
note: "Changing lanes should be done gradually and carefully to avoid collisions. 'Before you change lanes: … Be sure there is enough space for your vehicle in the next lane. It is not necessary to slow down before a lane change.'"

question: If you are driving on a highway next to a single broken white line marking:
options: "a: You cannot cross the line to pass.,b: You may cross the line to pass and change lanes.,c: You may only cross the line to change lanes if you are in the left lane."
note: "A broken white line indicates that you may cross the line to pass or change lanes."

question: Roads with double solid yellow line markings down the center indicate that passing is:
options: "a: Allowed from both directions.,b: Allowed only from your direction of travel.,c: Not allowed from either direction."
note: "Double solid yellow lines indicate a lane barrier between a regular use and a preferential use lane, such as a carpool (HOV) lane. You may also see double solid white lines in or near freeway on and off ramps. Never change lanes over double solid white lines. Wait until you see a single broken white line. "

question: When changing lanes:
options: "a: Check your side mirror and look over your shoulder to make sure the lane is clear.,b: Check the inside rearview mirror.,c: Slow down."
note: "The DMV handbook states that before changing lanes, you should 'Check your mirrors. Check traffic behind and beside you. Look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move to make sure the lane is clear.'"

question: Which of the following increases your chances of being in a collision?
options: "a: Looking over your shoulder while making lane changes,b: Continuously changing lanes to pass other vehicles,c: Adjusting your rearview mirror before you start driving"
note: "Continuously changing lanes to pass other vehicles increases the risk of collision.  'Stay in one lane as much as possible. Do not weave in and out of traffic. Last minute lane or direction changes may increase the risk of collisions.'"

question: You are driving in the far right lane of a four-lane freeway and notice thick broken white lines on the left side of your lane. You are driving in:
options: "a: The carpool lane and must merge into the next lane.,b: A special lane for slow-moving vehicles.,c: An exit lane."
note: "According to page 14, 'Ending freeway and street lanes are usually marked with large broken lines. If you are driving in a lane marked with broken lines, be prepared to exit the freeway or for the lane to end.'"

question: You are driving a slow moving vehicle on a winding two-lane highway. You must pull over when it is safe and let other drivers pass when you are followed by
options: "a: 3 vehicles,b: 4 vehicles,c: 5 or more vehicles"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, ‘You must use a turnout area or lane to let other vehicles pass when you are driving slowly on a two-lane road, where passing is unsafe, and there are five or more vehicles following you.'"

question: You may drive a motor vehicle in a bike lane:
options: "a: If you drive more slowly than 15 mph.,b: No more than 200 feet before making a right turn.,c: Whenever bicyclists are not present."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'It is illegal to drive in a bicycle lane unless you are: Parking (where permitted), Entering or leaving the road, Turning (within 200 feet of an intersection).'"

question: If a truck or bus is making a right turn where you also need to make a right turn, you should:
options: "a: Quickly turn before the truck or bus is able to.,b: Wait until the truck or bus turns before you turn.,c: Squeeze between the truck or bus and the curb."
note: "The DMV handbook states that when turning right, you should drive close to the right edge of the road.  It also states that when turning right from a one-way street onto a one-way street, you should start the turn in the far-right lane.  This means you should wait for the truck or bus to turn before you turn, rather than quickly turning before them or squeezing between them and the curb."

question: When making a right turn from a highway with two lanes traveling in your direction, you may turn from:
options: "a: The lane closest to the center of the road.,b: The lane nearest the curb or edge of the roadway.,c: Either lane"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, when making a right turn from a highway with two lanes traveling in your direction, you may turn from 'the lane nearest the curb or edge of the roadway'."

question: When preparing to make a left turn from a two-way street, you should drive:
options: "a: Near the right-hand side of the road.,b: Near the centerline.,c: On the left of the centerline."
note: "To make a left turn, you should drive 'close to the center divider or into the left turn lane.'"

question: In which lane should you end your turn when making a right turn?
options: "a: Any lane free of traffic.,b: The lane closest to the left edge of the road.,c: The lane closest to the right edge of the road."
note: "To make a right turn, you should end your turn in the lane closest to the right edge of the road. 'Do not swing wide into another lane of traffic.'"

question: A U-turn is not permitted:
options: "a: In a parking lot.,b: On or near any curve or hill.,c: On a straight roadway with a clear view for 500 feet in both directions."
note: "The DMV handbook states that you cannot make a U-turn 'When you cannot see clearly for 200 feet in each direction.' (Page 20).  Therefore, a U-turn is not permitted on or near any curve or hill."

question: U-turns in business districts are:
options: "a: Always illegal because they are dangerous.,b: Legal whenever oncoming vehicles are not a hazard.,c: Legal at intersections"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 20 that U-turns are never legal in business districts. 'Never make a U-turn: ... in business districts (the part of a city or town where most offices and businesses are).'"

question: You may make a left turn on a red light only from a:
options: "a: One-way street onto a two-way street.,b: One-way street onto a one-way street.,c: Two-way street onto a one-way street."
note: "You may turn left against a red light when you are turning from a one-way street onto a one-way street. Make sure there is no sign prohibiting the turn. Yield to other vehicles, pedestrians, or bicyclists who have a green light. Look both ways and turn when it is safe."

question: To turn left from a one-way street onto a one-way street, start from:
options: "a: The lane closest to the left curb.,b: The center lane.,c: Any lane"
note: "According to page 21, 'To turn left from a one-way street onto a one-way street. Start the turn from the far-left lane.'"

question: When turning left from a two-way street onto a one-way street, you should:
options: "a: Turn into any lane.,b: Turn into first lane.,c: Turn into second lane."
note: "According to page 21 of the DMV handbook, 'If there are three or more lanes in your direction of travel, you may end your turn in any lane that is open.'"

question: When you enter a freeway from an on ramp and merge with traffic, you should be driving at
options: "a: The legal speed limit on the freeway,b: About the same speed as the freeway traffic,c: About 10 m.p.h. slower than the freeway speed limit"
note: "The DMV handbook states that when merging onto a highway, 'Be in the proper lane on the on-ramp. - Be at or near the speed of traffic.'"

question: If you have a green light, but traffic is blocking the intersection, you should
options: "a: Enter the intersection and wait until traffic clears,b: Merge into another lane and try to go around the traffic,c: Stay out of the intersection until traffic clears"
note: "Even if you have a green light, do not start across the intersection if there are pedestrians or vehicles blocking your pathway.  'It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: How long before changing lanes on a freeway should you signal?
options: "a: 1-2 seconds,b: 2-4 seconds,c: 3-5 seconds"
note: "The California Driver's Handbook states, 'Signal at least five seconds before you change lanes on a freeway.' This is the same as 'approximately 400 feet'."

question: If you miss your exit on the freeway, you should not:
options: "a: Continue on the freeway and find an alternate route to your destination.,b: Proceed to the next exit,c: Back up on the road or shoulder."
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, page 23,  'If you miss your exit, continue around until you return to your exit.'"

question: When entering traffic after being parked at a curb, you:
options: "a: Should drive more slowly than other traffic for 200 feet.,b: Should wait for a large enough gap to get up to the speed of traffic.,c: Should wait for the first two vehicles to pass"
note: "The DMV handbook states that when entering traffic from a full stop, signal and leave a large enough space to get up to the speed of traffic."

question: If a traffic signal is green, but traffic is blocking the intersection, what should you do?
options: "a: Partially enter the intersection as allowed by traffic.,b: Wait and do not enter the intersection until your vehicle can get completely across.,c: Drive around the traffic on the shoulder to help ease the congestion."
note: "Even if you have a green light, do not start across the intersection if there are pedestrians or vehicles blocking your pathway. 'It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: If an oncoming vehicle has started to turn left in front of you
options: "a: Maintain your speed and take your right of way,b: Honk your horn to warn the driver and maintain your speed,c: Slow or stop to prevent a collision"
note: "When turning left, do not assume that an oncoming vehicle with its right turn signal on is turning before it reaches you. The driver may have their signal on by mistake or plan to turn just beyond you. Wait for the vehicle to start its turn before beginning the left turn."

question: You want to pass a vehicle on the road. You should
options: "a: Wait until you can see the entire vehicle in your rearview mirror before merging back into your lane,b: Use your horn to alert the other driver of your intention to pass,c: Pass only if there is enough space in the lane ahead of the vehicle,d: None of the above"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Unless you have enough space to return to your lane.' This means you should only pass if there is enough space in the lane ahead of the vehicle."

question: Where is it safe to pass another vehicle?
options: "a: Within an intersection where there are no oncoming vehicles,b: Wherever signs and/or pavement markings permit passing,c: Within a curve where there are no oncoming vehicles"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'You must judge whether you have enough space to pass whenever you approach: An oncoming vehicle or bicyclist., A hill, curve, intersection, or road obstruction.'  The DMV handbook explains, 'To safely pass, the hill or curve should be at least one-third of a mile ahead.'"

question: When it is legal to drive off the road to pass another vehicle?
options: "a: If the vehicle ahead is turning left.,b: It is not legal under any conditions.,c: If there are two or more one-way lanes."
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, 'Never drive off the paved or main-traveled part of the road to pass.'"

question: If you are being passed in a no passing zone, you should:
options: "a: Pull off the road.,b: Maintain your speed and position.,c: Slow down and let the other driver safely return to the drive lane."
note: "If a vehicle is passing you or signals that they plan on passing, allow the vehicle to pass. Maintain your lane position and your speed."

question: In addition to setting your parking brake, what should you do when parking on a hill?
options: "a: Make sure the front vehicle wheels are parallel to the road.,b: Make sure your vehicle is left in the 'neutral' position.,c: Make sure your vehicle is in the 'park' position or in gear."
note: "When you park on a hill, your vehicle could roll due to equipment failure.  Remember to set the parking brake and leave the vehicle in park, or in gear for manual transmission."

question: To safely back their vehicle, drivers should NOT
options: "a: Tap their horn before backing up,b: Check in front and behind their vehicle before they get in,c: Look over their right shoulder as they back up"
note: "Before backing up, it is important to check for hazards in front and behind the vehicle. 'Observe traffic and check appropriate blind spots.' (Page 26)"

question: When you park on a hill, your vehicle could roll due to an equipment failure. Remember
options: "a: Leave the vehicle in neutral,b: Set the parking brake,c: Set the parking brake and leave the vehicle in park"
note: "The DMV Handbook states: 'Remember to set the parking brake and leave the vehicle in park, or in gear for manual transmission.'"

question: If you parallel park facing downward on a hill:
options: "a: Turn your wheels sharply toward the side of the road.,b: Turn your wheels away from the side of the road.,c: Keep your wheels straight."
note: "To park on a hill headed downhill, turn your front wheels into the curb or right toward the side of the road."

question: When parking your vehicle parallel to the curb on a level street:
options: "a: Your front wheels must be turned toward the street.,b: Your wheels must be within 18 inches of the curb.,c: One of your rear wheels must touch the curb."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, when parallel parking your vehicle, 'Your vehicle should now be parallel and within 18 inches of the curb.'"

question: If you park facing uphill where there is no curb, set the parking brake and:
options: "a: Turn your wheels toward the edge of the road.,b: Turn your wheels away from the edge of the road.,c: Keep your wheels facing straight."
note: "As quoted in the DMV handbook: 'Headed either uphill or downhill when there is no curb: Turn the wheels so the vehicle will roll away from the center of the road if the brakes fail. Downhill: turn the wheels toward the curb.'"

question: Which way do you turn your front wheels to park downhill next to a curb?
options: "a: Into the curb,b: Away from the curb,c: Parallel to the curb"
note: "To park downhill next to a curb, turn your front wheels into the curb. This will prevent your car from rolling into the street if your brakes fail. 'Headed downhill: Turn your front wheels into the curb or right toward the side of the road.'"

question: Who can legally park next to curb painted blue?
options: "a: Someone who is either picking up or dropping off passengers at this location.,b: A person who is disabled and has a special placard or vehicle license plate for disabled persons.,c: A person who will only be parked at the curb for less than 15 minutes."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'Blue: Parking for a disabled person or someone driving a disabled person with a special placard or special license plate.'"

question: Parking is never permitted
options: "a: In a crosshatched (diagonal) pattern space,b: In a bicycle lane unless otherwise posted,c: Twenty feet from a railroad track"
note: "According to page 28, 'Never park or leave your vehicle... In the crosshatched (diagonal lines) area next to a designated disabled parking space.'"

question: A curb painted red means:
options: "a: Loading zone.,b: The area is reserved for picking up or dropping off passengers.,c: No parking"
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, 'Red: No stopping, standing, or parking.'"

question: If it is necessary to make an emergency stop while driving on an interstate, you should:
options: "a: Sound your horn at passing cars to get their attention.,b: Get out of your vehicle and flag down the first vehicle that passes.,c: Pull off the road"
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 28, 'If you must stop on a freeway, park completely off the pavement and stay in your vehicle with the doors locked until help arrives.'"

question: Placard abuse will result in:
options: "a: Placard revocation only.,b: Only a fine.,c: Placard revocation"
note: "Placard abuse will result in Placard revocation. This information can be found on Page 28, 'Illegal Parking', under the 'Blue' colored curb description."

question: A solid yellow arrow on a traffic signal means:
options: "a: You should speed up so you can make the turn before the light changes.,b: You do not need to signal to turn from the indicated lane.,c: You should prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic."
note: "A yellow arrow means the protected turning time is ending. The signal will change soon. If you cannot stop safely or you are already in the intersection, cautiously complete your turn. Pay attention to the next signal. It could be a: - Green or red traffic signal light. - Red arrow."

question: Before stopping your vehicle at a traffic signal or sign, you should:
options: "a: Press down hard on the accelerator.,b: Check your mirrors for surrounding traffic.,c: Set the parking brake."
note: "Before stopping at a traffic signal or sign, it is crucial to be aware of your surroundings to make safe driving decisions. The DMV handbook states that you should check your mirrors for surrounding traffic before entering an intersection."

question: When approaching an intersection that is controlled by a flashing red traffic signal, you must:
options: "a: Come to a complete stop,b: Reduce your speed and proceed with caution.,c: Come to a complete stop and remain stopped as long as the light is red."
note: "A flashing red traffic signal light means STOP. After stopping, you may go when it is safe."

question: When is it safe to enter an intersection on a solid green light?
options: "a: when you can go around the traffic already in the intersection,b: when you have enough space to cross the intersection before the light turns red,c: when you cannot completely cross the intersection"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Only proceed if you have enough space without creating a danger to any oncoming vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian. Do not enter the intersection if you cannot get completely across before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: It is against the law to enter an intersection when:
options: "a: You can't get all the way across before the light turns red.,b: The light is flashing yellow and you didn't stop first.,c: The light is yellow and you cannot stop safely."
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 34, 'Do not enter the intersection if you cannot get completely across before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: When coming to a corner where there is a stop sign, you must first stop
options: "a: After crossing the crosswalk,b: Out far enough to see cross traffic,c: In back of the crosswalk"
note: "According to page 35, 'Make a full stop before entering the crosswalk or at the limit line. If there is no limit line or crosswalk, stop before entering the intersection.'"

question: Blue traffic signs offer information on:
options: "a: Motorist services.,b: Construction and maintenance.,c: Mileage information"
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 36, 'White Rectangular Sign' communicates many important rules you must obey."

question: Regulatory signs are
options: "a: Suggestions,b: Law,c: Warnings"
note: "On page 37, the DMV handbook states that 'Red and White Regulatory Sign Follow the sign's instruction.'"

question: A diamond-shaped sign means:
options: "a: Yield.,b: Stop.,c: Warning."
note: "A diamond-shaped sign warns you of specific road conditions and dangers ahead."

question: What should you do when reaching an intersection where a person operating a motorized wheelchair has entered the crosswalk?
options: "a: Remain stopped behind the crosswalk line until the motorized wheelchair has safely finished crossing.,b: Remain stopped behind the nearest crosswalk line until the motorized wheelchair is beyond the range of your vehicle.,c: Assume right-of-way if the motorized wheelchair stops in the crosswalk."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Pedestrians always have the right-of-way.' This includes people with disabilities using a wheelchair. Therefore, you should remain stopped until the motorized wheelchair has safely finished crossing."

question: What happens if two vehicles reach at the same time an intersection with four-way stop signs?
options: "a: The driver on the right yields to the driver on the left,b: The driver on the left yields to the driver on the right,c: The first vehicle to reach the intersection must yield"
note: "The DMV Handbook states that 'If a vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist gets to the intersection at the same time as you, give the right-of-way to the vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist on your right.'"

question: At an intersection with a yield sign, you:
options: "a: Must yield the right-of-way to cross traffic that is close enough to cause conflict.,b: Must yield to vehicles only on your right.,c: Should slow down but never stop."
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 38, 'Slow down and be ready to stop to let any vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian pass before you proceed.'"

question: If there is no crosswalk and you see a pedestrian crossing your lane, you should:
options: "a: Make sure the pedestrian can see you before proceeding.,b: Cautiously drive around the pedestrian.,c: Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing."
note: "Pedestrians always have the right-of-way, even in unmarked crosswalks. 'Before entering an intersection, look left, right, and ahead to check for vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians. Be prepared to slow down and stop if necessary. Pedestrians always have the right-of-way.'"

question: What should a driver do who is stopped at an intersection and wants to make a left turn?
options: "a: Turn immediately if there are no pedestrians.,b: Take the right-of-way turn before oncoming traffic.,c: Give the right-of-way to any approaching vehicle that is close enough to be dangerous."
note: "When turning left, you must check for pedestrians. 'Give the right-of-way to any pedestrian or approaching vehicle that is close enough to be dangerous.'"

question: At an intersection with stop signs at all four (or more) corners, when two cars arrive at the same time you must yield the right-of-way to the driver
options: "a: On your right,b: On your left,c: Signaling a turn"
note: "The DMV handbook states: 'If a vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist gets to the intersection at the same time as you, give the right-of-way to the vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist on your right.'"

question: You face a green light, but traffic on the other side of the intersection does not allow you to travel all the way through the intersection. What must you do?
options: "a: Wait for the next green light,b: Wait until traffic ahead clears so you do not block the intersection,c: Enter the intersection and wait until traffic ahead clears"
note: "It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.  'It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: A driver who approaches an intersection
options: "a: Must yield the right-of-way to traffic already in the intersection,b: Has the right-of-way over traffic already in the intersection,c: Must drive straight through the intersection even if another vehicle is already in the intersection"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'When entering traffic, you must proceed with caution and yield to the traffic already occupying the lanes.' This statement clearly indicates that a driver approaching an intersection must yield to traffic already in the intersection."

question: Blocking an intersection during "rush hour" traffic is not permitted:
options: "a: Unless you entered the intersection on a green light.,b: Under any circumstances,c: Unless you have the right-of-way or a green light."
note: "It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.  This is found on page 39."

question: When planning to pass another vehicle, you should:
options: "a: Not count on other drivers to make room for you.,b: Assume the driver will let you pass if you use your turn signal.,c: Assume the driver will maintain a constant speed."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Never assume that other drivers will give you the right-of-way.'"

question: Once in the roundabout, drivers travel
options: "a: In a counter-clockwise direction,b: In a clockwise direction,c: In both directions"
note: "In a roundabout, traffic travels in one direction around a central island.  'Travel in a counter-clockwise direction. Do not stop or pass.'"

question: If a motorist sees pedestrians in an upcoming crosswalk, what should the motorist do?
options: "a: Continue ahead. The motorist has the right-of-way.,b: Wait for the pedestrians to cross the street.,c: Pull to the right and go around the pedestrians."
note: "Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks. 'If there is a limit line before the crosswalk, stop at the limit line and allow pedestrians to cross the street.'"

question: If you see a pedestrian using a guide dog or carrying a white cane:
options: "a: The pedestrian must yield the right-of-way.,b: You must yield the right-of-way.,c: Honk your horn to let them know you are there."
note: "Pedestrians using guide dogs or white canes have the right-of-way at all times.  'Be careful when you are turning or backing up. This is particularly important if you are driving a hybrid or electric vehicle because blind pedestrians rely on sound to know there is a vehicle nearby.'"

question: There is no crosswalk and you see a pedestrian crossing your lane ahead. You should:
options: "a: Make eye contact with and then pass the pedestrian.,b: Slow down as you pass the pedestrian.,c: Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing the street."
note: "Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks. If there is a limit line before the crosswalk, stop at the limit line and allow pedestrians to cross the street."

question: A safety zone is a specially marked area for passengers to get on or off buses or trolleys. You may not drive through a safety zone:
options: "a: Only when a bus or trolley is present.,b: Only when a bus or trolley is unloading passengers.,c: At any time or for any reason."
note: "The DMV handbook states 'Safety zones are spaces set aside for pedestrians waiting for buses, streetcars, and trolleys. Safety zones are marked by raised buttons or markers on a road. Do not drive through a safety zone under any condition.'"

question: Large trucks turning onto a street with two lanes in each direction:
options: "a: May complete the turn in either of the two lanes.,b: Often have to use the left lane to complete the turn.,c: Must stay in the right lane at all times while turning."
note: The DMV Handbook states on page 42: 'When a vehicle turns, the rear wheels follow a shorter path than the front wheels. The longer the vehicle, the greater the difference in the length of the turning path. This is why large vehicles and truck drivers must often swing wide to complete a turn.'"

question: Which of the following statements about blind spots is true?
options: "a: They are eliminated if you have one outside mirror on each side of the vehicle.,b: Large trucks have bigger blind spots than most passenger vehicles.,c: Blind spots can be checked by looking in your rearview mirrors."
note: "The DMV handbook states that large vehicles and truck drivers have a better view in front of them and bigger mirrors, but they also have large blind spots, also called No Zones.  'In these areas, your vehicle can disappear from a large vehicle or truck driver's view. If you cannot see the truck's side mirrors, the truck driver cannot see you.'"

question: A safety zone is a specially marked area for passengers to get on or off of buses or trolleys. You may not drive through a safety zone:
options: "a: When a bus or trolley is present.,b: When a bus or trolley is unloading passengers.,c: At any time for any reason."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Safety zones are spaces set aside for pedestrians waiting for buses, streetcars, and trolleys.' It then goes on to say, 'Do not drive through a safety zone under any condition.'"

question: When following a motorcycle, drivers must remember that motorcycles can ____________ than other vehicles.
options: "a: Accelerate much faster,b: Stop much more quickly,c: Stop much more slowly"
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 44, 'Allow a safe three-second following distance. This space will help you avoid hitting a motorcyclist if they brake suddenly or fall.'"

question: You are driving on a city street and see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights behind you. What should you do?
options: "a: Drive to the right edge of the road and slow down.,b: Drive to the right edge of the road and stop.,c: Stay in your lane slow down and let it pass."
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, 'Give the right-of-way to any law enforcement vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren and red lights. Failure to pull over may result in a ticket. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle(s) have passed.'"

question: Motorcycles, scooters, and mopeds are not easy to see; therefore, you should:
options: "a: Slow down when driving.,b: Make constant visual checks.,c: Share a lane with a motorcycle."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Motorcycles are smaller in size and harder to see so they easily disappear in vehicle blind spots.'"

question: You are crossing an intersection and an emergency vehicle is approaching while using its siren and flashing lights. You should:
options: "a: Stop immediately in the intersection until it passes.,b: Pull to the right of the intersection and stop.,c: Continue through the intersection"
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, 'Give the right-of-way to any law enforcement vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren and red lights. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle(s) have passed.'"

question: Large trucks are likely to lose speed when:
options: "a: Driving up long or steep hills.,b: Driving in long,c: Driving down long"
note: "Large trucks, bicycles, and some cars lose speed on long or steep hills. 'Large trucks, bicycles, and some cars lose speed on long or steep hills.'"

question: If you are driving and you see animals standing near the roadway:
options: "a: Speed up to scare them away.,b: Slow down and proceed with caution.,c: Quickly swerve into the next lane."
note: "If you see a sign with a picture of an animal, watch for animals on or near the road. If you see animals or livestock near the road, slow down or stop and proceed when it is safe."

question: You want to pass a bicyclist riding on the right edge of your lane. You
options: "a: must honk your horn before passing the bicyclist,b: must not squeeze past the bicyclist,c: may not pass the bicyclist for any reason"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'When you cannot change lanes to pass a bicyclist, allow at least three feet between your vehicle and the bicyclist. If you cannot give three feet of space, do not pass the cyclist until three feet of clearance can be given.'"

question: Which sign on a truck means that the truck's load is potentially dangerous?
options: "a: Octagonal.,b: Diamond shaped.,c: Rectangular wide.,d: None of the above"
note: "A diamond-shaped sign on a truck means that the truck's load may be dangerous (gas, explosives etc.)."

question: Fines in a construction zone are:
options: "a: Doubled.,b: Tripled.,c: Cut in half."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 49, 'Fines are also doubled in highway construction or maintenance zones when workers are present.'"

question: If you are continually being passed on the right and the left while driving in the center lane of an expressway, you should:
options: "a: Stay in the center lane.,b: Move to the lane on your right.,c: Move to the lane on your left."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, on a multilane road, the passing lane is on the far left, and the right lane is used to enter or exit traffic.  The DMV handbook states that if you are driving slower than the flow of traffic, you should drive in the right lane. 'If you choose to drive slower than other traffic, drive in the right lane.' (Page 49)"

question: When driving in work zones, you should:
options: "a: Follow the driver in front of you closely.,b: Pass the driver in front of you as soon as you can.,c: Avoid tailgating and keep a safe following distance."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 49, 'Go through the work zone carefully by: ... Allowing extra space between vehicles.'"

question: Which of the following is true about vehicles displaying a diamond-shaped sign that indicates a hazardous load?
options: "a: They are not allowed to drive on freeways.,b: They must stop before crossing railroad tracks.,c: They are not allowed to exceed 35 mph."
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 49, 'Vehicles with these signs **must** stop before crossing railroad tracks.'"

question: Work zone barriers, drums, cones, and signs are used to:
options: "a: Make drivers angry about slow traffic.,b: Inconvenience drivers.,c: Keep traffic out of hazardous work zones."
note: "Cones, drums, and barriers are used to keep traffic out of a hazardous work zone. 'Go through the work zone carefully by: Slowing down.' 'Cones, drums, or other barriers will guide you through the work zone.' "

question: What should you do when there is a school bus ahead that starts flashing yellow warning lights?
options: "a: Slow down and prepare to stop.,b: Stop immediately and remain stopped.,c: Cautiously pass the school bus on the left."
note: "When a school bus flashes yellow lights, you must slow down and prepare to stop. 'Some school buses flash yellow lights when preparing to stop to let children off the bus. The yellow flashing lights warn you to slow down and prepare to stop.'"

question: You are passing a school and see children near the street. You may not drive faster than
note: "The DMV handbook states 'The speed limit is 25 mph within 500 feet of a school while children are outside or crossing the street.'"

question: If you pass a school bus that is stopped with its red lights flashing, you will:
options: "a: Be fined up to $1000,b: Be fined up to $100.,c: Face no legal consequences."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, on page 50, 'If you fail to stop, you may be fined up to $1,000 and your driving privilege could be suspended for one year.'"

question: When a school bus is stopped ahead on your side of the road with its red lights flashing, you must:
options: "a: Slow to a speed no faster than 10 mph.,b: Stop until the lights stop flashing.,c: Change lanes and pass cautiously."
note: "When the bus flashes red lights (located at the top, front, and back of the bus), you must stop from either direction until the children are safely across the street and the lights stop flashing. Remain stopped while the red lights are flashing."

question: Which of the following statements is true?
options: "a: Driving too slowly is not an unsafe practice.,b: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.,c: The speed at which you drive a vehicle does not affect safety."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'You must drive slower when there is heavy traffic or bad weather. At the same time, you should not block normal and reasonable traffic flow by driving too slowly. If you drive faster or slower than the speed limit, you may be cited.'"

question: You must stop at the intersection ahead. Just before the intersection, you have to cross railroad tracks. You should stop before you cross the railroad tracks when
options: "a: You don’t have room to completely cross the tracks,b: The crossing is located in a city or town with frequent train traffic,c: You transport two or more children in a passenger vehicle"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'Never stop on the railroad tracks. Wait and do not begin proceeding if you do not have enough room to completely cross the tracks. If you are on the tracks, you risk injury or death.'"

question: The speed limit in any alley is
options: "a: 25 MPH,b: 20 MPH,c: 15 MPH"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 51: 'The speed limit in an alley is 15 mph.'"

question: At a railroad crossing, you must:
options: "a: Watch for vehicles that must stop at all railroad crossings (school buses),b: Watch for multiple trains.,c: Both of the above."
note: "The DMV handbook states that you must 'Expect a train on any track, at any time, traveling in either direction.' and  'Watch for vehicles that must stop before they cross train tracks. These vehicles include buses, school buses, and vehicles marked with a hazardous materials placard.'"

question: When crossing a sidewalk to enter traffic from an alley or driveway, drivers should:
options: "a: Stop only if pedestrians are on the sidewalk.,b: Stop before driving onto the sidewalk or sidewalk area.,c: Expect pedestrians on the sidewalk to yield the right-of-way."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'You may drive on or cross a sidewalk to enter or exit a driveway or alley.'  This means drivers should stop before driving onto the sidewalk or sidewalk area."

question: You have stopped for a train at a railroad crossing. After the train passes, you should:
options: "a: Wait for signal lights to stop flashing.,b: Look for a second train.,c: Both of the above."
note: "The DMV Handbook states on page 51 that, 'When the crossing devices or a person warns you a train is coming, stop at least 15 feet from the nearest track.' The DMV handbook also states that, 'Do not proceed over the railroad tracks until the red lights stop flashing, even if the gate rises.'"

question: Which of these vehicles must always stop before crossing railroad tracks?
options: "a: Tank trucks with hazardous materials placards.,b: Motor homes or pickup trucks towing a boat trailer.,c: Sport utility vehicles carrying four or more persons."
note: "According to page 50, 'Vehicles with these signs must stop before crossing railroad tracks.'"

question: A passenger vehicle may NOT tow
options: "a: One trailer,b: Another passenger vehicle,c: Two trailers"
note: "The DMV Handbook states on page 52, 'You must drive in the far-right lane or a lane marked for slower vehicles when you: … Tow a vehicle or trailer.' It also states, 'You cannot carry anything in or on a passenger vehicle which extends beyond the fenders on the left side or more than 6-inches beyond the fenders on the right side.'"

question: Abandoning an animal on the highway may result in:
options: "a: Jail time.,b: A point against your license.,c: No legal consequences."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'You must not dump or abandon animals on a highway. This crime is punishable by a fine of up to $1,000, six months in jail, or both.'"

question: Smoking inside a vehicle with a person younger than 18 years of age is:
options: "a: Legal,b: Illegal at all times.,c: Not restricted by law."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'You must: Not smoke when a minor is in the vehicle. You can be fined.' This information is found on page 52."

question: Any driver who willfully flees or attempts to evade law enforcement, during which a person is seriously injured, is subject to:
options: "a: Imprisonment in a state prison for up to seven years.,b: A fine of less than $1000.,c: Attending an anger-management class."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'A person convicted of causing serious bodily injury during a law enforcement pursuit is subject to imprisonment in a state prison for up to seven years, or a county jail for one year or less.'"

question: If you are repeatedly convicted for traffic violations
options: "a: DMV may impound your vehicle,b: Your driving privilege may be suspended by DMV,c: Both of the above"
note: "The DMV book states, ’DMV monitors your driver's record. As an adult or minor, if you get a traffic ticket and fail to appear (FTA) in court, DMV may suspend your driving privilege...As an adult, your license may be suspended if your driver's record shows one of the following point totals: 4 points in 12 months., 6 points in 24 months., 8 points in 36 months.'"

question: A person convicted of reckless driving or engaging in a speed contest that causes injury to another person is subject to
options: "a: imprisonment and a fine,b: community service,c: all the above"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'A person convicted of reckless driving or engaging in a speed contest that causes injury to another person is subject to imprisonment, a fine, or both.'"

question: A peace officer is signaling for you to drive to the edge of the roadway. You decide to ignore the officer's warning and flee the scene. You are guilty of a misdemeanor and can be punished by being:
options: "a: Fined up to $1000,b: Jailed in the county jail for not more than one year.,c: Given a warning and a citation."
note: "The DMV handbook, on page 53, states: 'It is a misdemeanor to use a motor vehicle to flee or attempt to evade law enforcement performing their duties. This is punishable by imprisonment in a county jail for one year or less.'"

question: Which of the following is an example of a safe driving practice?
options: "a: Staring only at the middle of the road.,b: Always keep your eyes moving to scan the surroundings.,c: Using your high-beam headlights in the fog"
note: "The DMV Handbook states to 'always keep your eyes moving and scan the road at least 10 seconds ahead of your vehicle' on page 57."

question: If you become angry or upset, you should
options: "a: Go for a drive to forget your problems,b: 'Cool off' before driving,c: Control your emotions while driving"
note: "The DMV Handbook emphasizes the importance of controlling your emotions while driving, stating: 'If you become angry or upset, you should 'cool off' before driving.'"

question: On a freeway, drivers should look farther ahead than they normally would on a city street
options: "a: Because it takes 500 feet to stop a vehicle on a freeway,b: In order to spot potential hazards and dangers ahead,c: Because there are multiple lanes"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'To give yourself time to react, avoid last minute moves and hazards, always keep your eyes moving and scan the road at least 10 seconds ahead of your vehicle.'"

question: Tailgating
options: "a: Is a defensive driving technique,b: Cannot result in a traffic citation,c: Can frustrate other drivers and make them angry"
note: "Tailgating is following too closely, which can 'frustrate other drivers and make them angry.'  The DMV handbook states that it is important to leave a safe following distance. "

question: Interstate driving requires drivers to:
options: "a: Have the ability to safely drive at increased speeds.,b: Be constantly alert.,c: Both of the above."
note: "Interstate driving requires drivers to 'Be aware of your surroundings' and  'Manage your speed' which are both required to drive safely at increased speeds. The DMV handbook provides the following in the section 'Be Aware Of Your Surroundings' on Page 57:  'To drive safely, you need to know what is around you. This helps you make good decisions and react to hazards on the road.'"

question: While driving, you should look 10 to 15 seconds ahead of you:
options: "a: And focus on the middle of the road.,b: Because it is a legal requirement.,c: To see potential hazards early."
note: "To give yourself time to react, avoid last minute moves and hazards, always keep your eyes moving and scan the road at least 10 seconds ahead of your vehicle."

question: Blind spots are:
options: "a: Spots in your vision when you become fatigued.,b: Areas of the road that cannot be seen in a vehicle's mirrors.,c: Traffic control devices."
note: "Blind spots are 'areas around the vehicle that a driver cannot see when looking straight ahead or using the mirrors.' (Page 58)"

question: Make room for cars that are entering the freeway by:
options: "a: Slowing down.,b: Merging into a different lane.,c: Maintaining your speed and position."
note: "According to page 22, 'Make space for vehicles entering freeways, even if you have the right-of-way.'"

question: To see vehicles in your blind spots, you should check:
options: "a: The inside rearview mirror.,b: The outside rearview mirror.,c: Over your shoulders."
note: "To check your blind spots, look over your right and left shoulders out of your side windows. Only turn your head when you look. Do not turn your whole body or steering wheel."

question: When driving at night, you should:
options: "a: Always use your high beams.,b: Look directly at the headlights of an oncoming vehicle.,c: Increase your following distance."
note: "When driving at night, you should increase your following distance. This gives you more time to react if the driver in front of you brakes suddenly."

question: When passing a row of parked vehicles, you should:
options: "a: Be prepared for a person or vehicle to unexpectedly enter your lane.,b: Expect all other drivers and pedestrians to respect your right-of-way.,c: Drive closely to the parked vehicles to allow more room for moving traffic."
note: "'Keep space between your vehicle and parked vehicles.'  It is important to be prepared for a person or vehicle to unexpectedly enter your lane when passing parked vehicles, as they may be hidden from view and may not be aware of your presence. "

question: You are on the freeway and traffic is merging into your lane. You should:
options: "a: Make room for the merging traffic,b: Assert your right-of-way by driving faster.,c: Always maintain your position."
note: "Highway traffic has the right-of-way. 'Make space for vehicles entering freeways, even if you have the right-of-way. Be ready for rapid changes and watch for signals from other drivers.'"

question: When driving at night with no other vehicles ahead, a driver should use
options: "a: High beam lights,b: Low-beam lights,c: Parking lights"
note: "When driving at night with no other vehicles ahead, a driver should use high-beam headlights. 'When driving at night, use your high-beam headlights on open country roads or dark city streets.'"

question: When driving at night on a dimly lit street, you should:
options: "a: Drive slowly enough that you can stop within the area illuminated by your headlights.,b: Turn on your high beam headlights to better see the vehicles ahead of you.,c: Keep the instrument panel lights bright to be more visible to other drivers."
note: "The DMV Handbook states that 'Make sure you can stop in the distance lit by your headlights.' on page 59, when discussing driving at night.  This means driving slowly enough to be able to stop within the area illuminated by your headlights."

question: If your vehicle begins to skid, you should:
options: "a: Ease up on the gas pedal.,b: Brake as hard as possible.,c: Turn off the ignition."
note: "The DMV handbook states that if your vehicle begins to skid, you should slowly remove your foot from the accelerator.  'If you start to skid, follow these steps: 1. Slowly remove your foot from the accelerator. 2. Do not use the brakes.'"

question: You exit the freeway on a ramp that curves downhill. You should:
options: "a: Slow to a safe speed before the curve.,b: Slow to the posted speed limit for the freeway.,c: Wait until you have entered the curve to begin braking."
note: "You should always slow down before entering a curve, especially one that is downhill. 'Slow down as you approach intersections and curves. For sharp curves, slow down as you approach and move through.'"

question: Streets and highways are most slippery:
options: "a: When it has been raining hard for several hours.,b: When they are clean and dry.,c: Just after it starts to rain."
note: "The DMV Handbook states 'When it starts to rain, the pavement can be very slippery.' This is because oil and dust on the road surface have not been washed away. "

question: Water on the road can cause a vehicle to hydroplane. Your car may hydroplane at speeds as low as:
options: "a: 45 miles per hour.,b: 35 miles per hour.,c: 40 miles per hour."
note: "Hydroplaning occurs when driving in wet or rainy conditions.  Hydroplaning is when a vehicle rides on water because the tires lose all contact with the road. A slight change of direction, applying the brakes, or a gust of wind could throw the vehicle into a skid.  To avoid hydroplaning: Drive slowly. Steer around standing water, if possible. Slow down if you hear sloshing sounds from the tires. Slow down when changing lanes or direction."

question: Which of the following is most likely to be slippery in cold weather after snow or rain?
options: "a: A hilly,b: A residential road,c: A road in a shaded area"
note: "According to page 61, 'Shade from trees or buildings can hide icy spots on cold, wet days. These areas freeze first and dry out last.'"

question: Which of the following roadways freeze first when wet?
options: "a: Bridges and overpasses,b: Intersections,c: Tunnels"
note: "Bridges and overpasses tend to freeze before the rest of the road because they can have icy spots."

question: If you find that the roadway ahead of you is flooded, you should:
options: "a: Slam on the brakes.,b: Not drive through the flooded area. Turn around and find another route.,c: Drive only in the center of the roadway."
note: "The DMV handbook states that it may not be possible to determine the depth of a flooded road by looking.  It also states that if the water is deep, the road may be too dangerous to cross. 'It may not be possible to determine the depth of the flood by looking. If the water is deep, the road may be too dangerous to cross. It is best to find another route.'"

question: When driving at night, you should:
options: "a: Always use your high beams.,b: Look directly at the headlights of an oncoming vehicle.,c: Increase your following distance."
note: "When driving at night, you should increase your following distance to give yourself more time to react to hazards.  The DMV handbook states, 'Increase your following distance.'"

question: When driving in fog, you should use your:
options: "a: Fog lights only.,b: High beams.,c: Low beams."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'If you must drive in heavy fog or smoke:  - Drive slowly.  - Use your low-beam headlights. High-beam headlights will reflect back and cause glare.  - Never drive using only your parking or fog lights.' "

question: Which of the following is true about safety belts?
options: "a: They can reduce injuries and deaths,b: They can trap you inside a vehicle,c: They are not necessary when driving around town"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 64 that 'Wearing the lap belt and shoulder harness of a seat belt will increase your chance of survival in most types of collisions.'"

question: If bad weather makes it difficult for you to see clearly, you should:
options: "a: Speed up to get off the road quickly.,b: Drive in the lane closest to oncoming traffic.,c: Increase your following distance."
note: "When you drive in fog or smoke, you should 'increase your following distance'  because you may not be able to see as far ahead. This gives you more time to react if you encounter a hazard."

question: Who must wear seat belts?
options: "a: The driver and all passengers under the age of 21,b: The driver and all passengers 8 years of age or older or children who are 4 feet 9 inches tall or taller,c: The driver and front seat passengers"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'You must secure children with a federally-approved child passenger restraint system or safety belt. The requirements depend on the child's height and age.'  It goes on to say that 'Children who are 8 years old or older, or at least 4 feet 9 inches tall: May use a properly secured safety belt that meets federal standards.'"

question: In a vehicle equipped with airbags, the safest place for children age 12 and under to ride is in:
options: "a: The front seat.,b: The back seat.,c: The bed of a pick-up truck."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'Children who are under 8 years old, or who are less than 4 feet 9 inches tall: Secure in a child passenger restraint system in a rear seat.'"

question: It is illegal to leave a child age six or younger unattended in a vehicle on a hot day:
options: "a: Even if they are secured in a child passenger restraint system.,b: If they are supervised by a person twelve years of age or older.,c: Only if the key is in the ignition."
note: "The DMV handbook states 'It is illegal to leave a child who is six years old or younger unattended in a vehicle...' and 'A child may be left under the supervision of a person who is at least 12 years old.'"

question: What is the maximum speed limit on two-lane undivided highways, unless otherwise posted?
options: "a: 45 MPH,b: 65 MPH,c: 55 MPH"
note: "The DMV handbook states that the ideal maximum speed limit on most California highways is 65 mph. It is 55 mph on a two-lane undivided highway and for vehicles towing trailers."

question: If you drive at the posted speed limit, you can be given a speeding ticket
options: "a: Under no circumstances,b: If you are carrying more than one passenger,c: If road or weather conditions require a slower speed"
note: "'In California, you may never drive faster than is safe for the current road conditions. This is known as the Basic Speed Law. Make sure you manage your speed and slow down when conditions call for it.'"

question: Which of the following blocks the smooth flow of traffic?
options: "a: Slowing down to look at collision scene.,b: Avoiding unnecessary lane changes.,c: Using public transportation instead of your vehicle."
note: "The DMV Handbook states that 'Small changes in your driving habits can help reduce congestion. Avoid weaving in and out of freeway lanes.'  This means that slowing down to look at a collision scene can be disruptive to traffic flow."

question: You are driving on a freeway with a posted speed limit of 65 mph. Traffic is traveling at 70 mph. You may legally drive:
options: "a: 70 mph or faster to keep up with the speed of traffic.,b: Between 65 mph and 70 mph.,c: No faster than 65 mph."
note: "In California, you may never drive faster than is safe for the current road conditions. This is known as the Basic Speed Law. Make sure you manage your speed and slow down when conditions call for it. Regardless of the posted speed limit, your speed should depend on: The number of vehicles on the road. The speed of other vehicles on the road. The road surface: smooth, rough, graveled, wet, dry, wide, or narrow. Bicyclists or pedestrians on or crossing the road. Weather: rain, fog, snow, wind, or dust. Traffic congestion: small changes in your driving habits can help reduce congestion. Avoid weaving in and out of freeway lanes."

question: If you want to pass a pedestrian who is walking along the roadway and an oncoming vehicle is approaching, you should:
options: "a: Slow down and let the oncoming vehicle pass before you pass the pedestrian.,b: Keep driving at a steady speed. The oncoming vehicle must stop for you.,c: Honk your horn to get the pedestrian to move over."
note: "The DMV handbook states that if you are on a two-lane road with an oncoming vehicle and a pedestrian, you should 'take one danger at a time'.  This means you should slow down and allow the oncoming vehicle to pass before attempting to pass the pedestrian."

question: If your accelerator becomes stuck you should
options: "a: Turn off the ignition while the vehicle is moving,b: Not apply the brakes. Ease off the gas pedal and straighten the front wheels,c: Shift to neutral apply the brakes and try to drive the car safely off the road"
note: "If your accelerator becomes stuck, you should 'Shift to neutral, apply the brakes, and try to drive the car safely off the road.'"

question: If your wheels drop off the roadway or pavement edge, you should:
options: "a: Wait until it is safe to do so,b: Turn back onto the roadway immediately.,c: Stop."
note: "If your wheels drift off the pavement, you should: 1. Grip the steering wheel firmly. 2. Remove your foot from the accelerator. 3. Brake gently. 4. Check for traffic behind you. 5. Carefully steer back onto the pavement. Do not pull or turn your steering wheel with too much force. This may cause you to drive into oncoming traffic."

question: If your car becomes disabled while on the highway, you should:
options: "a: Stop in the right lane.,b: Park with all four wheels off the traveled highway,c: Stop where you are."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'If your vehicle stops working on the freeway: 1. Safely pull over to the right shoulder. 2. Exit on the right side so you are away from traffic if you must get out of the vehicle.'"

question: Distracted driving is:
options: "a: Anything that causes evasive action while driving.,b: Anything that takes your attention away from driving.,c: Anything that causes you to pay more attention to driving."
note: "Distracted driving is defined as anything that takes your attention away from driving. 'Avoid distractions while you drive.' (DMV handbook, page 70)"

question: What is a likely effect when you take another drug while you drink alcohol?
options: "a: There are no effects unless the drug is prescription only,b: If the drug is over-the-counter there are no effects,c: The effects of the alcohol and the drug are enhanced"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 72, 'It is illegal to drive after… Using any combination of alcohol or drugs that decreases your ability to drive safely.'"

question: Driving under the influence of any medication which impairs your driving is permitted:
options: "a: Under no circumstances.,b: If you don't feel drowsy.,c: If it is prescribed by a physician."
note: "It is illegal to drive under the influence of any drug that affects your ability to drive safely.  'The law does not see a difference between illegal drugs and medications you get from a doctor or pharmacy. They can all affect your ability to drive safely and react to what you see and hear.' (Page 72)"

question: Which of these statements is true about drugs and driving?
options: "a: Any prescription drug is safe to use if you don't feel drowsy.,b: Even over-the-counter drugs can impair your driving.,c: Only illegal drugs can impair your driving."
note: "The DMV Handbook states that 'The law does not see a difference between illegal drugs and medications you get from a doctor or pharmacy. They can all affect your ability to drive safely and react to what you see and hear.'"

question: If you are arrested for drunk driving and refuse to submit to a chemical test of the alcohol content of your blood
options: "a: Your driving privilege will be withdrawn,b: You will receive an additional fine,c: You will not be allowed to post bail"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, if you refuse to take a blood or urine test after being suspected of driving under the influence, 'DMV will suspend or revoke your driving privilege for one year.'"

question: BAC is
options: "a: The acronym for Beer Accumulation,b: The number of ounces of alcohol in your blood,c: The percentage of alcohol in your blood"
note: "The DMV handbook defines BAC as 'Your BAC is the amount of alcohol in your blood.'"

question: How many alcoholic drinks does it take to affect your driving ability?
options: "a: Three,b: Two,c: One"
note: "According to the DMV Handbook on page 73, 'Remember even one drink can affect your ability to drive safely.'"

question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) that is ____ or higher.
options: "a: 0.08% -- Eight-hundredths of one percent,b: 0.10% -- One-tenth of one percent,c: 0.05% -- Five-hundredths of one percent"
note: "The correct answer is 0.08%.  This information can be found on page 73 of the DMV handbook. The DMV handbook states, 'It is illegal for you to drive if you have a BAC of: 0.08% or higher if you are over 21 years old.'"

question: Which of these statements is true about drinking alcohol and driving?
options: "a: If you can walk in a straight line after drinking,b: If you are under the legal blood alcohol concentration limit,c: Alcohol affects judgement"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Almost everyone feels negative effects of alcohol, even at levels lower than the legal limit.' This means that even if you're under the legal BAC limit, alcohol can still affect your judgment and make you an unsafe driver."

question: If a police officer asks you to take an alcohol test, you may choose:
options: "a: A blood breath or urine test,b: A field sobriety test,c: To say the alphabet backwards"
note: "On page 74, the DMV Handbook states: 'When you drive in California, you consent to a breath, blood, or urine test if a law enforcement officer suspects you of DUI.'"

question: If you are convicted of driving with an excessive blood alcohol concentration (BAC), you may be sentenced to serve:
options: "a: Up to six months in jail.,b: Up to 12 months in jail.,c: No jail time"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 74 that you may be sentenced to up to six months in jail if convicted of a DUI. 'If you are convicted of a DUI, DMV will suspend or revoke your driving privilege for one year.'"

question: You must make a financial responsibility report after an accident when damage to one of the vehicles is over $750
options: "a: Only if you are not insured,b: Only if it was your fault,c: No matter who was at fault"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 77 that you must report the accident to DMV within 10 days if 'The collision caused more than $1,000 in damage to property.'"

question: If you are the first person to stop to give assistance at a collision scene, you should drive to the side of the road
options: "a: After you have passed the collision scene,b: Before you reach the collision scene,c: Next to the collision scene"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 77: 'If you are in a collision, you must stop. Someone could be injured and need your help.'"

question: If you are involved in a traffic accident in California, you must file a report of the accident with the DMV when:
options: "a: The collision causes $1000,b: You plan on being out of the state for more than 30 days.,c: You refinance the remaining balance of your vehicle loan."
note: "According to page 77 of the California Driver's Handbook, 'You must report it to DMV within 10 days if:  - The collision caused more than $1,000 in damage to property.'"

question: Slowing down just to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary:
options: "a: Causes traffic congestion.,b: Prevents rear-end collisions.,c: Improves traffic flow by preventing collisions."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'If you see a vehicle's emergency flashers ahead, slow down. There may be a collision or other road emergency. Pass carefully.'"

question: You have been involved in a minor traffic collision with a parked vehicle and you can't find the owner. You must:
options: "a: Leave a note on the vehicle.,b: Report the collision without delay to the city police or,c: Both of the above."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Try to find the owner if your vehicle hits or rolls into a parked car or other property. If you cannot find the owner, leave a note with your name, phone number, and address. Securely attach the note to the vehicle or property. Report the collision to law enforcement.'"

question: You hit a parked vehicle and can't find the owner. What must you do?
options: "a: Call your insurance company when you get home.,b: Wait for the owner to return.,c: Leave a note with your name and address on the parked vehicle."
note: "If you cannot find the owner, leave a note with your name, phone number, and address. Securely attach the note to the vehicle or property. Report the collision to law enforcement."

question: You must notify the DMV within 5 days if you:
options: "a: Fail a smog test for your vehicle,b: Sell or transfer your vehicle,c: Get a new prescription for lenses or contacts,d: None of the above"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 79, 'When you sell a vehicle, you must notify DMV within five days by completing a Notice of Transfer and Release of Liability at dmv.ca.gov/nrl.'"
